item.title: Life on Earth Depends on Networks of Ocean Bacteria
item.description: Nanotube bridge networks grow between the most abundant photosynthetic bacteria in the oceans, suggesting that the world is far more interconnected than anyone realized.
item.media:keywords: Quanta Magazine, science, health, bacteria, environment, oceans, Biology, Ecology
item.dc:creator: Veronique Greenwood
item.dc:subject: Support Network

item.title: Why People Act So Weirdly at Airports
item.description: Time and boundaries dissolve in these spaces while people become charged with stress, anxiety, and excitement. Throw in a drink or two, and it’s no wonder people aren’t themselves.
item.media:keywords: The Conversation, science, Airports, Travel, Air Travel, psychology
item.dc:creator: Steve Taylor
item.dc:subject: Feeling Flighty

item.title: The USAID Shutdown Puts Millions of African Lives at Risk
item.description: HIV research programs have been halted, and many treatment clinics are still closed, despite a waiver for “life-saving” humanitarian aid.
item.media:keywords: science, health, Africa, Nigeria, HIV, Donald Trump, public health, government
item.dc:creator: Taiwo Hassan
item.dc:subject: Public Health

item.title: Gutting USAID Will Have a Monumental Effect on Combating Climate Change
item.description: The agency was a key player in renewable energy and disaster protection around the world—until Elon Musk showed up.
item.media:keywords: Climate Desk, science, environment, Policy, government
item.dc:creator: Jake Bittle
item.dc:subject: Policy

item.title: How Morocco Became the Meteorite Hunting Capital of the World
item.description: Since the “Saharan Gold Rush” in the 1990s, one researcher has been fighting for the North African country’s contributions to science to be recognized.
item.media:keywords: science, Africa, space, rocks, environment, Books, Geology
item.dc:creator: Helen Gordon
item.dc:subject: Finders Keepers

item.title: Donald Trump's NIH Pick Just Launched a Controversial Scientific Journal
item.description: The journal’s editorial board includes multiple scientists, such as Trump health nominees Jay Bhattacharya and Marty Makary, who opposed Covid public health measures.
item.media:keywords: COVID-19, coronavirus, public health, research, Donald Trump
item.dc:creator: Emily Mullin, Matt Reynolds
item.dc:subject: science club

item.title: NOAA Employees Told to Pause Work With ‘Foreign Nationals’
item.description: An internal email obtained by WIRED shows that NOAA workers received orders to pause “ALL INTERNATIONAL ENGAGEMENTS.”
item.media:keywords: Donald Trump, politics, climate change, government, Policy
item.dc:creator: Dell Cameron
item.dc:subject: Government

item.title: This DOGE Engineer Has Access to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
item.description: Sources tell WIRED that NOAA employees were ordered to give an engineer from Elon Musk’s DOGE task force access to all of the agency’s Google sites by the end of business on Wednesday.
item.media:keywords: Elon Musk, government, NOAA, climate change, DOGE
item.dc:creator: Tim Marchman, Matt Giles
item.dc:subject: Takeover

item.title: ‘Dengue Boy’ Is the Weird, Fleshy Novel You Need Right Now
item.description: Dengue Boy, a book about a humanoid mosquito taking his revenge in the dying years of planet Earth, is unsettling and essential.
item.media:keywords: science, culture, environment, Books, mosquitos, infectious disease, Argentina, climate change
item.dc:creator: Matt Reynolds
item.dc:subject: Buzz Off

item.title: Early Detection Tools Help but They Can’t Stop Every Wildfire
item.description: Tree-mounted sensors and new satellites promise a way to detect wildfires before they get out of hand—but no early detection method is foolproof.
item.media:keywords: science, climate change, environment, wildfires, California, satellites
item.dc:creator: Matt Reynolds
item.dc:subject: California Wildfires

item.title: These Robots Are Recovering Dumped Explosives From the Baltic Sea
item.description: In the face of seabeds becoming valuable real estate and corroding bombs polluting the oceans, teams are turning to technology to clean up this dangerous and expensive problem.
item.media:keywords: science, war, Ammo and Munitions, environment, Germany, robots, artificial intelligence
item.dc:creator: Bryn Stole
item.dc:subject: Bombs Away

item.title: Why Computer Scientists Need Magic 8 Ball-Like Oracles
item.description: Hypothetical devices that can quickly and accurately answer questions have become a powerful tool in computational complexity theory.
item.media:keywords: Quanta Magazine, science, computer science
item.dc:creator: Ben Brubaker
item.dc:subject: Answer Me

item.title: Moon or Mars? The US Might Face a Tough Choice for Future Missions
item.description: Continuing the Artemis program and using its planned lunar space station as a staging post would be a more energy efficient but slower way to reach Mars, and it’s unlikely to be Elon Musk’s preference.
item.media:keywords: The Conversation, science, space, SpaceX, NASA, moon, Mars, Elon Musk
item.dc:creator: Ian Whittaker
item.dc:subject: Change of Plan

item.title: RFK Jr.’s Organic Crusade Has Sparked a Weird Political Realignment
item.description: Eating organic is normally associated with tote-wielding liberals, but RFK Jr. is shifting the politics of food in unusual ways.
item.media:keywords: science, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., farming, Donald Trump, food, pesticides, agriculture, health
item.dc:creator: Matt Reynolds
item.dc:subject: Eat Right

item.title: The Federal Funding Freeze Will Cause Lasting Damage to Medical Research
item.description: Clinical trials may have to be scrapped, research applications will be pushed back, and unpaid researchers will quickly leave the sector—even if the Trump administration’s funding pause is only temporary.
item.media:keywords: science, politics, research, Policy, health, Donald Trump
item.dc:creator: Jane Smith-Rogers
item.dc:subject: Critical Hit

item.title: RFK Jr.’s Senate Testimony Is Haunted by His Track Record
item.description: During his confirmation hearings this week, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said he would promote vaccines as HHS secretary, despite a long history of promoting anti-vax positions.
item.media:keywords: science, health, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Donald Trump, vaccines, politics
item.dc:creator: Emily Mullin
item.dc:subject: Trump Cabinet 2.0

item.title: Washington, DC, Plane Crash: Everything We Know So Far
item.description: Air traffic controllers asked Flight 5342 to switch runways when coming in to land. Black box recordings from the jet and the military helicopter it collided with will help reveal whether this contributed to the accident.
item.media:keywords: science, Safety, Aviation, emergency, disaster, transportation, Air Travel
item.dc:creator: Alec Luhn
item.dc:subject: Disaster

item.title: Trump’s Plan for Elon Musk to Bring the ‘Stranded’ Astronauts Home ASAP Is a Headache for NASA
item.description: Bringing forward the return of Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams would leave just a single astronaut operating the US portion of the International Space Station.
item.media:keywords: Ars Technica, science, Elon Musk, space, SpaceX, NASA, iss, Donald Trump, politics, boeing
item.dc:creator: Eric Berger, Ars Technica
item.dc:subject: Lost in Space

item.title: Federal Spending Freeze Threatens Ecosystems and Public Safety
item.description: A White House memo ordered a halt to federal assistance and a review to align spending with Donald Trump’s priorities. Many legal experts say the order is unconstitutional.
item.media:keywords: Climate Desk, government, Policy, environment, climate, science
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kusnetz
item.dc:subject: Policy

item.title: This Blood Vessel Was Grown in a Lab With Real Human Cells
item.description: The FDA recently approved a bioengineered blood vessel, which becomes part of a patient’s body over time. It’s designed to help treat victims of traumatic injuries.
item.media:keywords: science, biotech, health, Surgery, cells
item.dc:creator: Emily Mullin
item.dc:subject: spare parts
